question: Question 1 For [latex]A=\begin{bmatrix} 1 & tan x\\ -tan x &1 \end{bmatrix}[/latex], the Determinant of  [latex]A^{T}A^{-1}[/latex] is
solution: Long Method: [latex] \begin{aligned} A &=\left[\begin{array}{cc} 1 & \tan x \\ -\tan x & 1 \end{array}\right] \\ A^{T} &=\left[\begin{array}{cc} 1 & -\tan x \\ \tan x & 1 \end{array}\right] \\ \operatorname{ad} A &=\left[\begin{array}{cc} 1 & \tan x \\ -\tan x & 1 \end{array}\right] \\ A^{-1} &=\frac{1}{|A|}[a d j(A)]^{T} \\ &=\frac{1}{1+\tan ^{2} x}\left[\begin{array}{cc} 1 & -\tan x \\ \tan x & 1 \end{array}\right] \\ &=\frac{1}{\sec ^{2} x}\left[\begin{array}{cc} 1 & -\tan x \\ \tan x & 1 \end{array}\right] \end{aligned}[/latex] Here, [latex] \begin{aligned} A^{\top} A^{-1} &=\left[\begin{array}{cc} 1 & -\tan x \\ \tan x & 1 \end{array}\right] \frac{1}{\sec ^{2} x}\left[\begin{array}{cc} 1 & -\tan x \\ \tan x & 1 \end{array}\right] \\ &=\frac{1}{\sec ^{2} x}\left[\begin{array}{cc} 1-\tan ^{2} x & -2 \tan x \\ 2 \tan x & 1-\tan ^{2} x \end{array}\right] \\ A^{\top} A^{-1} &=\left[\begin{array}{cc} \frac{1-\tan ^{2} x}{\sec ^{2} x} & \frac{-2 \tan x}{\sec ^{2} x} \\ \frac{2 \tan x}{\sec ^{2} x} & \frac{1-\tan ^{2} x}{\sec ^{2} x} \end{array}\right] \\ \left|A^{T} A^{-1}\right| &=\left(\frac{1-\tan ^{2} x}{\sec ^{2} x}\right)^{2}+\left(\frac{2 \tan x}{\sec ^{2} x}\right)^{2} \\ &=\frac{1+\tan ^{4} x-2 \tan ^{2} x+4 \tan ^{2} x}{\sec ^{4} x}\\ &=1 \end{aligned}[/latex] Or Short Method: [latex] \begin{aligned} \text{since, }|A B|&=|A||B| \\ \left|A^{T} A^{-1}\right| &=\left|A^{T}\right|\left|A^{-1}\right| \\ &=|A| \times \frac{1}{|A|}=1 \\ &\left(\text { Note }:\left|A^{T}\right|=|A| \text { and }\left|A^{-1}\right|=\frac{1}{|A|} \right) \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 2 The contour on the x-y plane, where the partial derivative of [latex]x^{2}+y^{2}[/latex] with respect to y is equal to the partial derivative of 6y + 4x with respect to x, is
solution: Partial derivative w.r.t. [latex] \frac{\partial}{\partial y}\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right)=2 y[/latex] Partial derivative w.r.t. x [latex] \frac{\partial}{\partial x}(6 y+4 x)=4[/latex] From given condition [latex] \begin{aligned} 2 y&=4 \\ \Rightarrow y\quad &=2 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 3 If C is a circle of radius r with centre [latex]z_{0}[/latex], in the complex z-plane and if n is a non-zero integer, then [latex]\oint_{C}\frac{dz}{(z-z_{0})^{n+1}}[/latex] equals
solution: By Cauchy integral formula [latex] \begin{array}{l} \oint \frac{f(z)}{\left(z-z_{0}\right)^{n+1} d z}=\frac{2 \pi i f^{*}\left(z_{0}\right)}{n !} \\ \oint \frac{d z}{\left(z-z_{0}\right)^{n+1}}=\frac{2 \pi i}{n !} \cdot 0=0 \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 4 Consider the function [latex]g(t)=e^{-t}sin(2\pi t)u(t)[/latex] where u(t) is the unit step function. The area under g(t) is _______.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} g(t) &=e^{-t} \sin (2 \pi t) u(t) \\ \text { Area } &=\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} g(t) d t \\ &=\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \sin (2 \pi t) u(t) e^{-t} d t=\left.G(s)\right|_{s=0} \\ G(s) &=\frac{2 \pi}{(s+1)^{2}+4 \pi^{2}} \\ \text { Area } &=\left.\frac{2 \pi}{(s+1)^{2}+4 \pi^{2}}\right|_{S=0}=0.155 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 5 The value [latex]\sum_{n=0}^{\infty }n(\frac{1}{2})^{n}[/latex] is ______.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^{n} &=\sum_{n=-\infty}^{\infty} n\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^{n} u(n) \\ &=Z \cdot T\left[n\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^{n} u(n)\right]_{z=1} \\ =& \frac{\frac{1}{2} Z^{-1}}{\left(1-\frac{1}{2} z^{-1}\right)^{2}}=\left.\frac{\frac{Z}{2}}{\left(z-\frac{1}{2}\right)^{2}}\right|_{z=1} \\ =& \frac{1 / 2}{1 / 4}=2 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 6 For the circuit shown in the figure, the Thevenin equivalent voltage (in Volts) across terminals a-b is ________.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} V_{Th}&=V_{6\;\omega}\\ \frac{V_{A}-12}{3}+\frac{V_{A}}{6} &=V_{6 \Omega} \\ V_{A}\left[\frac{1}{3}+\frac{1}{6}\right] &=1+4 \\ V_{A} \frac{3}{6} &=5 \\ V_{T h} &=V_{6 \Omega}=V_{A}=10 \mathrm{V} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 7 In the circuit shown, the voltage [latex]V_{X}[/latex] (in Volts) is _______.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{V_{x}}{20}+\frac{V_{x}-V_{y}}{10}+0.5 V_{x}&=5 \mathrm{A} \\ V_{x}\left[\frac{1}{20}+\frac{1}{10}+0.5\right]&=5+\frac{V_{y}}{10} \\ 13 \mathrm{V}_{x}&=100+2 \mathrm{V}_{y} \quad\ldots(i)\\ \text { and also, } V_{y}&=0.25 \mathrm{V}_{x} \quad\dots(ii) \end{aligned}[/latex] Solving equations (i) and (ii), we have [latex] \begin{aligned} 52 V_{y} &=100+2 V_{y} \\ 50 V_{y} &=100 \Rightarrow V_{y}=2 \mathrm{V} \\ V_{x} &=4 V_{y}=8 \mathrm{V} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 8 At very high frequencies, the peak output voltage [latex]V_{0}[/latex] (in Volts) is ________.
solution: Circuit contains balanced Wheat-stone bridge. Also at high frequencies capacitor can be considered as short circuits. Redrawing the circuit [latex] \begin{aligned} V_{0} &=1 \sin \omega t \times 1 k \Omega=0.5 \sin \omega t \\ \text { Peak output } &=0.5 \mathrm{V} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 9 Which one of the following processes is preferred to form the gate dielectric ([latex]SiO_{2}[/latex]) of MOSFETs ?
solution: Dry oxidation is preferred for gate oxides.

question: Question 10 If the base width in a bipolar junction transistor is doubled, which one of the following statements will be TRUE?
solution: [latex] W_{B} [/latex] doubled (increased) [latex] \rightarrow [/latex] early effect is still present but its effect less severe relative to previous [latex] W_{B} [/latex]. Slope [latex] I_{C} [/latex] versus [latex] V_{C E} [/latex] decreases.

question: Question 11 In the circuit shown in the figure, the BJT has a current gain ([latex]\beta[/latex]) of 50. For an emitter-base voltage [latex]V_{EB}[/latex]= 600 mV, the emitter-collector voltage [latex]V_{EC}[/latex] (in Volts) is _______.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} V_{E B} &=0.7 \mathrm{V} \\ I_{B} &=0.0383 \mathrm{mA} \\ I_{C} &=1.916 \mathrm{mA} \\ V_{E C} &=3-I_{C} R_{C} \\ &=3-(1.916 \times 0.5)=2.04 \mathrm{V} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 12 In the circuit shown using an ideal opamp, the 3-dB cut-off frequency (in Hz) is _______.
solution: [latex]f_{3 \mathrm{dB}}=\frac{1}{2 \pi R C}=159.15 \mathrm{Hz}[/latex]

question: Question 13 In the circuit shown, assume that diodes [latex]D_{1} \;  and \; D_{2}[/latex] are ideal. In the steady state condition, the average voltage [latex] V_{ab}[/latex] (in Volts) across the 0.5 [latex]\mu[/latex]F capacitor is _____.
solution: The circuits work as a voltage doubler. [latex] \therefore V_{a b}=2 \times 50=100[/latex]

question:
Question 14 The circuit shown consists of J-K flip-flops, each with an active low asynchronous reset ([latex]\bar{R_{d}} [/latex] input).The counter corresponding to this circuit is
(
solution:
Q is applied as negative edge triggering clock. [latex]
\Rightarrow[/latex]  Counter is up counter. Reset signal [latex]=\overline{Q_{2} \cdot Q_{0}} [/latex] The counter resets at 101 [latex]
 \Rightarrow [/latex] Counter is MOD-5

question: Question 15 In the circuit shown, diodes [latex]D_{1} , D_{2} \;  and \; D_{3}[/latex] are ideal,  and the inputs [latex]E_{1} , E_{2} \;  and \; E_{3} [/latex] are  "0 V" for logic '0'  and  "10 V" for logic '1'. What logic gate does the circuit represent?
solution:
Case (i): If any input is logic 0 (i.e.,  0 V ) then 
corresponding diode is "ON" and due to ideal 
diode output voltage  [latex]V_{0}=0[/latex]  as well as if there is 
any input logic 1 (i.e.,  10 V) corresponding diode 
will be OFF. Case (ii): If all the inputs are high (i.e.,  10 V) then 
all the diodes are R.B. (OFF) and output voltage  [latex]
V_{0}=10 \mathrm{V} [/latex] So, it is a positive 3 -inputs AND gate.

question: Question 16 Which one of the following 8085 microprocessor programs correctly calculates the product of two 8-bit numbers stored in registers B and C?
solution:
Product can be obtained by repeated addition. Only {C) option satisfied addition repeatedly. Here register 'B' is used as count to add register 
'C' to accumulator, initially having OOH. Adding 
'B' times 'C' to accumulator.

options.A: MVI A, 00H JNZ LOOP CMP C LOOP: DCR B HLT
options.B: MVI A, 00H CMP C LOOP: DCR B JNZ LOOP HLT
options.C: MVI A, 00H LOOP: ADD C DCR B JNZ LOOP HLT
options.D: MVI A, 00H ADD C JNZ LOOP LOOP: INR B HLT

question: Question 17 The impulse response of an LTI system can be obtained by
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} IR&= \frac{d}{dt}(SR)\\ &\text{Step response,} \\ y(t)&=\int_{-\infty }^{t}h(\tau )\cdot d\tau \\ h(t)&= \frac{d}{dt}y(t) \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 18 Consider a four-point moving average filter defined by the equation [latex]y[n]=\sum_{i=0}^{3}\alpha _{i} x[n-i][/latex], The condition on the filter coefficients that results in a null at zero frequency is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} y(n)&=\sum_{i=0}^{3} \alpha_{i} x(n-i) \\ &=\alpha_{0}x[n]+\alpha_{1} x[n-1]+\alpha_{2} x[n-2]+\alpha_{3} x[n-3] \\ \Rightarrow Y(z)&=\alpha_{0} X(z)+\alpha_{1} X(z) z^{-1}+\alpha_{2} X(z) z^{-2} \\ & +\alpha_{3} X(z) z^{-3} \\ H(z)&=\alpha_{0}+\alpha_{1} z^{-1}+\alpha_{2} z^{-2}+\alpha_{3} z^{-3} \\ \text {Null at }&\text{zero frequency } \\ \Rightarrow \quad z&=\left.e^{j \omega}\right|_{\omega=0}\\ 0 &= \alpha_{0}+\alpha_{1}+\alpha_{2}+\alpha_{3} \end{aligned}[/latex] Option (A) satisfies the condition

question: Question 19 Consider the Bode plot shown in the figure. Assume that all the poles and zeros are real-valued. The value of [latex]f_{H}-f_{L}[/latex] (in Hz) is ___________.
solution: As we know, [latex] \begin{aligned} \text { Slope } &=\frac{y_{2}-y_{1}}{x_{2}-x_{1}} \\ \therefore \quad 40 \mathrm{dB} / \mathrm{dec} &=\frac{40-0}{\log 300-\log _{L}}\\ or, \log \left(\frac{300}{f_{L}}\right)&=\frac{40}{40}=1 f_{L}=30 \mathrm{Hz} \end{aligned}[/latex] Similarly, [latex] \begin{aligned} -40 \mathrm{dB} / \mathrm{dec}&=\frac{40-0}{\log 900-\log f_{H}}\\ \log \left(\frac{900}{f_{H}}\right) &=-1 \\ \text { or, } \quad f_{H}&=9000 \mathrm{Hz} \\ \text { Therefore, } f_{H}-f_{L}&=9000-30 =8970 \mathrm{Hz} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 20 The phase margin (in degrees) of the system [latex]G(s)=\frac{10}{s(s+10)}[/latex] is _______.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} G(s) &=\frac{10}{s(s+10)} \\ P M &=180^{\circ}+\left.\angle G(\omega) H(\omega)\right|_{\omega=\omega_{g c}} \end{aligned} [/latex] The gain cross over frequency can be calculated by [latex] \begin{aligned} |G(\omega) H(\omega)|&=1 \\ \frac{10}{\omega \sqrt{\omega^{2}+100}}&=1 \\ \omega_{g c}^{4}+100 \omega_{g c}^{2}&-100=0\\ \text { Or } \quad \omega_{g c}^{2}&=0.99, \quad-100.99 \\ \text { Or } \quad \omega_{g c}&=0.99 \text { rad/sec. } \\ \therefore P M &=180^{\circ}+\left(-90^{\circ}-\tan ^{-1} \frac{\omega_{g c}}{10}\right) \\ &=180^{\circ}-90^{\circ}-\tan ^{-1} \frac{0.99}{10} \\ & \simeq 84.364^{\circ} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 21 The transfer function of a first-order controller is given as [latex]G_{c}(s)=\frac{K(s+a)}{s+b}[/latex] where K, a and b are positive real numbers. The condition for this controller to act as a phase lead compensator is
solution: For phase lead compensator [latex] \begin{aligned} G_{c}(s)&=\frac{(1+s \tau)}{(1+\alpha s \tau)} \quad ; \quad \alpha \lt 1\\ \text{Here,}\quad \tau&=\frac{1}{a}\\ \text{and}\quad \alpha \tau&=\frac{1}{b}\\ \text{or,}\quad \alpha&=\frac{a}{b} \lt 1\\ \text{or,}\quad a& \lt b \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 22 The modulation scheme commonly used for transmission from GSM mobile terminals is
solution: (GMSK) is used to transmit GSM signals.

question: Question 23 A message signal [latex]m(t)=A_{m} sin(2\pi f_{m}f)[/latex] is used to modulate the phase of a carrier [latex]A_{c}cos(2\pi f_{c}t)[/latex] to get the modulated signal [latex]y(t)=A_{c} cos(2\pi f_{c}t+m(t))[/latex].  The bandwidth of y(t).
solution: The bandwidth of a PM signal is given by [latex] B=2\left(\Delta f+f_{m}\right)[/latex] Now, for single tone PM signal [latex] \begin{aligned} \Delta f&=A_{m} K_{\rho} f_{m} \\ \therefore \quad B&=2\left(K_{p} A_{m}+1\right) f_{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

options.D: does not depend on [latex]A_{m} or f_{m}[/latex]

question: Question 24 The directivity of an antenna array can be increased by adding more antenna elements, as a larger number of elements
solution: Directivity (0) is increased by adding more antenna elements in an antenna array. Effective area [latex](A_{e})[/latex] and directivity (D) are related by [latex] A_{e}=\frac{\lambda^{2}}{4 \pi} D [/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow D \uparrow A_{e} \uparrow[/latex]

options.B: increases the effective area of the antenna
options.C: results in a better impedance matching
options.D: allows more power to be transmitted by the antenna

question: Question 25 A coaxial cable is made of two brass conductors. The spacing between the conductors is filled with Teflon ( [latex]\varepsilon^{'}_{r}[/latex]= 2.1, tan [latex]\delta[/latex]=0). Which one of the following circuits can represent the lumped element model of a small piece of this cable having length [latex]\Delta[/latex]z?
solution: The teflon dielectric between the lines has [latex] \tan \delta=\text{Loss tangent}=0[/latex] For the medium between the lines [latex] G=0[/latex]

question: Question 26 The Newton-Raphson method is used to solve the equation [latex]f (x) = x^{3}- 5x^{2} + 6x- 8 = 0 [/latex]. Taking the initial guess as x = 5, the solution obtained at the end of the first iteration is __________.
Question 27 A fair die with faces {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6} is thrown repeatedly till '3' is observed for the first time. Let X denote the number of times the die is thrown. The expected value of X is ____.
Question 28 Consider the differential equation [latex]\frac{d^{2}x(t)}{dt^{2}}+3\frac{dx(t)}{dt}+2x(t)=0[/latex]. Given x(0) = 20 and x(1) = 10/e, where e = 2.718, the value of x(2) is _________.

Question 29 A vector field [latex]D=2\rho ^{2} a_{\rho }+z a_{z}[/latex] exists inside a cylindrical region enclosed by the surfaces [latex]\rho[/latex]= 1, z = 0 and z = 5. Let S be the surface bounding this cylindrical region. The surface integral of this field on [latex]S(\oint\oint_{S} D.ds)[/latex]  is _______.
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{c} \vec{D}=2 \rho^{2} \hat{a}_{p}+z \hat{a}_{z} \\ \text { surface: } \rho=1, z=0 \text { and } z=5 \\ \oiint_{s} \vec{D} \cdot ds=\int_{\text {Top surface}} \vec{D} \cdot ds \\ +\int_{\text {Bottom surface}} \vec{D} \cdot ds \\ +\int_{\text {curved surface }} \vec{D} \cdot ds \\ =5 \pi+0+20 \pi=25 \pi=78.54 \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 30 In the circuit shown, the current I flowing through the 50 [latex]\Omega [/latex] resistor will be zero if the value of capacitor C (in [latex]\mu[/latex]F) is ______.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} Z_{\mathrm{eq}} &=\frac{j 5 \Omega \times\left(\frac{1}{j \omega C}+j 5\right)}{j 5 \Omega+j 5 \Omega+\frac{1}{j \omega C}} \\ I &=0 \text { if } Z \text { is } \infty \\ Z &=Z_{\mathrm{eq}}+50+j 5\\ \text{For z to be } \infty, Z_{e q}&=\infty \\ \Rightarrow j 5+j 5+\frac{1}{j \omega C}&=0\\ 10 &=\frac{1}{5000 \times C} \\ C &=\frac{1}{5 \times 10^{3} \times 10}=20 \mu \mathrm{F} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 31 The ABCD parameters of the following 2-port network are
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \left[\begin{array}{l} V_{1} \\ I_{1} \end{array}\right] &=\left[\begin{array}{ll} A & B \\ C & D \end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{l} V_{2} \\ I_{2} \end{array}\right] \\ \text { When } I_{2} &=0 \\ V_{1} &=(5+j 4+2) I_{1} \\ V_{2} &=2 I_{1} \\ A &=\left.\frac{V_{1}}{V_{2}}\right|_{I_{2}=0}=\frac{7+j 4}{2}=3.5+j 2 \\ C &=\left.\frac{I_{1}}{V_{2}}\right|_{I_{2}=0}=\frac{1}{2}=0.5 \end{aligned}[/latex] Option (B) matches. From here only

question: Question 32 A network is described by the state model as [latex]\dot{x_1}=2x_{1}-x_{2}+3u [/latex] [latex]\dot{x_2}=-4x_{2}-u[/latex] [latex] y=3x_{1}-2x_{2}[/latex] The transfer function [latex]H(s)(=\frac{Y(s)}{U(s)})[/latex] is
solution: State matrix form: [latex] \begin{array}{l} \dot{x}=\left[\begin{array}{cc} 2 & -1 \\ 0 & -4 \end{array}\right] x+\left[\begin{array}{c} 3 \\ -1 \end{array}\right] u \\ y=\left[\begin{array}{ll} 3 & -2 \end{array}\right] x \end{array}[/latex] The transfer function from tate matrix can be calculated as: [latex] T(S)=C(s l-A]^{-1} B+D[/latex] Here, [latex] [s l-A]^{-1}=\left[\begin{array}{cc} s-2 & 1 \\ 0 & s+4 \end{array}\right]^{-1}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} &=\frac{1}{(s-2)(s+4)}\left[\begin{array}{cc} (s+4) & -1 \\ 0 & (s-2) \end{array}\right] \\ \Rightarrow &C[s /-A]^{-1} B \\ =& \frac{1}{(s-2)(s+4)}[3-2]\left[\begin{array}{cc} (s+4) & -1 \\ 0 & (s-2) \end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{c} 3 \\ -1 \end{array}\right] \\ =& \frac{1}{(s-2)(s+4)}[3-2]\left[\begin{array}{c} 3 s+12+1 \\ -s+2 \end{array}\right] \\ =& \frac{1}{(s-2)(s+4)}[9 s+39+2 s-4] \\ =& \frac{11 s+35}{(s-2)(s+4)} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 33 The electric field profile in the depletion region of a p-n junction in equilibrium is shown in the figure. Which one of the following statements is NOT TRUE?
solution: Built in potential, [latex] \begin{aligned} \Psi_{0} &=\frac{1}{2} \times\left(10^{6} \mathrm{V} / \mathrm{m}\right) \times\left(1.1 \times 10^{-6} \mathrm{m}\right) \\ &=0.55 \mathrm{Volts} \end{aligned}[/latex] But in question (option (c)) is given as 700 mV.

options.A: The left side of the junction is n-type and the right side is p-type
options.B: Both the n-type and p-type depletion regions are uniformly doped
options.C: The potential difference across the depletion region is 700 mV
options.D: If the p-type region has a doping concentration of [latex]10^{15} cm^{-3}[/latex], then the doping concentration in the n-type region will be [latex]10^{16} cm^{-3}[/latex]

question: Question 34 The current in an enhancement mode NMOS transistor biased in saturation mode was measured to be 1 mA at a drain-source voltage of 5 V. When the drain-source voltage was increased to 6 V while keeping gate-source voltage same, the drain current increased to 1.02 mA. Assume that drain to source saturation voltage is much smaller than the applied drain-source voltage. The channel length modulation parameter  [latex]\lambda[/latex] (in [latex]V^{-1}[/latex]) is _______.
solution: [latex]\lambda=\frac{\Delta I_{D}}{I_{D} \Delta V_{D S}}=\frac{0.02 \mathrm{mA}}{1 \mathrm{mA} \times 1 \mathrm{V}}=0.02[/latex]

question: Question 35 An npn BJT having reverse saturation current [latex]I_{S} = 10^{-15}[/latex] A is biased in the forward active region with [latex]V_{BE}[/latex] = 700 mV. The thermal voltage ( [latex]V_{T}[/latex] ) is 25 mV and the current gain ([latex]\beta[/latex]) may vary from 50 to 150 due to manufacturing variations. The maximum emitter current (in [latex]\mu[/latex]A) is ________.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} I_{C} &=I_{s} e^{V_{B E} / V_{T}} \\ I_{E} &=\frac{\beta+1}{\beta} I_{C} \\ &=\frac{\beta+1}{\beta} I_{S} \cdot e^{V_{B E} / V_{T}} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] I_{E}[/latex] will be maximum when [latex]\beta[/latex] is 50. [latex] \begin{aligned} &=(1.02)\left(10^{-9} \times 10^{-6}\right) e^{\frac{700 \times 10^{-3}}{25 \times 10^{-3}}} \\ &=1475 \mu \mathrm{A} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 36 A three bit pseudo random number generator is shown. Initially the value of output
[latex]Y \equiv Y_{2} Y_{1} Y_{0}[/latex] is set to 111. The value of output Y after three clock cycles is
solution: The given circuit is similar to After three clock Y is 100.

question: Question 37 A universal logic gate can implement any Boolean function by connecting sufficient number of them appropriately. Three gates are shown. Which one of the following statements is TRUE?
solution:
Universal gate is a gate by which every other gate 
can be realized. Gate 1 and Gate 2 are basic gates and can not 
be used as universal gates.

options.D: None of the gates shown is a universal gate

question: Question 38 An SR latch is implemented using TTL gates as shown in the figure. The set and reset pulse inputs are provided using the push-button switches. It is observed that the circuit fails to work as desired. The SR latch can be made functional by changing
solution:
For TTL gate, open end acts as logic '1 '. 
So if we connect 5 V battery to ground then 
pressing the switches allow logic 'O' while opening 
the switches allow logic '1 '. In case of 5 V battery 
both opening and closing of switches allow 
logic '1' and hence circuit can't act as SR latch.

options.C: NOR gates to NAND gates and inverters to buffers

question: Question 39 In the circuit shown, assume that the opamp is ideal. If the gain ([latex]v_{o} / v_{in}[/latex]) is -12, the value of R (in k[latex]\Omega[/latex]) is _____.
solution: Apply nodal analysis at inverting terminal [latex] \frac{V_{\text {in }}-0}{10 \mathrm{k} \Omega}=\frac{0-V_{x}}{10 \mathrm{k} \Omega}[/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow \quad V_{\text {in }}=-V_{x} \qquad\ldots(i)[/latex] Again apply nodal analysis at node [latex]V_{x} [/latex] [latex] \frac{0-V_{x}}{10 k \Omega}=\frac{V_{x}-0}{R}+\frac{V_{x}-V_{0}}{10 k \Omega}\qquad\ldots(ii)[/latex] Put the value of V from equation (i) in equation  (ii), we get [latex] R = 1\Omega[/latex]

question:
Question 40 In the circuit shown, both the enhancement mode NMOS transistors have the following characteristic: [latex]k_{n}=\mu _{n} C_{ox}(W/L)=1 mA/V^{2};V_{TN}=1V[/latex]. Assume that the channel length modulation parameter [latex]\lambda[/latex]
 is zero and body is shorted to source. The minimum supply voltage [latex]V_{DD}[/latex] (in
volts) needed to ensure that transistor [latex]M_{1}[/latex] operates in saturation mode of operation is _______.
solution: Lower transistor [latex]\left(M_{1}\right) [/latex] to work in saturation [latex] V_{D S_{1}} \geq V_{G S_{1}}-V_{T N}[/latex] So, for minimum [latex]V_{D D} [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} V_{D S_{1}} &=V_{G S 1}-V_{T N} \\ V_{D S_{1}} &=2-1=1 \mathrm{V} \\ \therefore \quad V_{D_{1}} &=1 \mathrm{V}\\ \text{and}\quad I_{D_{1}}&=K^{\prime}\left(V_{G S_{1}}-V_{T N}\right)^{2}\\ I_{D_{1}}&=\frac{1 \mathrm{mA}}{V^{2}} \times(2-1)^{2}=1 \mathrm{mA} \end{aligned}[/latex] Now transistor [latex]M_{2}, V_{D G}=0 V [/latex] So, it will work into saturation region and same current will flow. [latex] \begin{aligned} I_{D_{2}}&=I_{D_{1}}=K^{\prime}\left(V_{G S_{2}}-V_{T N}\right)^{2} \\ 1 \mathrm{mA}&=1 \mathrm{mAN}^{2} \times\left(V_{D D}-1-1\right)^{2} \\ &\left(\because V_{S_{2}}=V_{D_{1}}\right)\\ \therefore \quad V_{D D}&=3 \mathrm{V} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 41 In the circuit shown, assume that the diodes [latex]D_1 \; and \; D_2[/latex] are ideal. The average value of voltage [latex]V_{ab}[/latex] (in Volts), across terminals 'a' and 'b' is _________.
solution: During positive cycles: [latex]V_{1}=\frac{V_{\text {in }}}{2} [/latex] During negative cycles: [latex]V_{0}=\frac{V_{\text {in }}}{3} [/latex] [latex] V_{D C}=\frac{V_{m}}{2} \cdot \frac{1}{\pi}+\frac{V_{m}}{3} \cdot \frac{1}{\pi}=\frac{6 \pi}{2 \pi}+\frac{6 \pi}{3 \pi}=5 \mathrm{V}[/latex]

question: Question 42 Suppose x[n] is an absolutely summable discrete-time signal. Its z-transform is a rational function with two poles and two zeroes. The poles are at [latex]z = \pm 2j[/latex]. Which one of the following statements is TRUE for the signal x[n]?
solution:
Poles are at  [latex]z=\pm 2 [/latex] Since  x[n]  is absolutely summable hence, DTFT 
exists which implies ROC must include unit circle. [latex]
 \Rightarrow x(t) [/latex] is a non-causal signal.

options.A: It is a finite duration signal.

question: Question 43 A realization of a stable discrete time system is shown in the figure. If the system is excited by a unit step sequence input x[n], the response y[n] is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{Y(z)}{X(z)}&=\frac{\frac{5}{3}[1-z]}{z^{2}-z+\frac{2}{9}} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \eta (z)&=\frac{5}{3} \frac{(1-z)}{\left(z-\frac{1}{3}\right)\left(z-\frac{2}{3}\right)}\\ \eta(z) &=\frac{5 z}{z-\frac{1}{3}}-\frac{5 z}{z-\frac{2}{3}} \\ y(n) &=5\left(\frac{1}{3}\right)^{n} u(n)-5\left(\frac{2}{3}\right)^{n} u(n) \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 44 Let [latex]\tilde{x}[n]=1+cos(\frac{\pi n}{8})[/latex] be a periodic signal with period 16. Its DFS coefficients are defined by [latex]a_{k}=\frac{1}{16}\sum_{n=0}^{15}\tilde{x}[n]exp(-j\frac{\pi }{8}kn)[/latex] for all k . The value of the coefficient [latex]a_{31}[/latex] is _______.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \tilde{x}[n]&=1+\cos \left(\frac{\pi n}{8}\right)\\ &=1+\frac{e^{\left(\frac{2 \pi}{16}\right)} h}{2}+\frac{e^{-\left(\frac{2 \pi}{16}\right)}}{2} &(N=16)\\ &=1+\frac{e^{\left(\frac{2 \pi}{16}\right)}}{2}+\frac{e^{-\left(\frac{2 \pi}{16}\right)}}{2} \\ \Rightarrow a_{1}&=\frac{1}{2}\text{ and also } a_{31}=a_{15}=a_{-1}=\frac{1}{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 45 Consider a continuous-time signal defined as [latex]x(t)=(\frac{sin(\pi t/2)}{(\pi t/2)})*\sum_{n=-\infty }^{\infty }\delta (t-10n)[/latex] where '*' denotes the convolution operation and t is in seconds. The Nyquist sampling rate (in samples/sec) for x(t) is _____.
solution: [latex]x(t)=\frac{\sin \left(\frac{\pi t}{2}\right)}{\left(\frac{\pi t}{2}\right)} * \sum_{n=-\infty}^{\infty} \delta[t-10 n][/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} f_{\max } &=0.2 \mathrm{Hz} \\ \Rightarrow \quad f_{s} &=2 f_{\max }=0.4 \mathrm{Hz} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 46 The position control of a DC servo-motor is given in the figure. The values of the parameters are [latex]K_{T}=1 N-m/A[/latex], [latex]R_{a}=1 \Omega [/latex], [latex] L_{a}=0.1H,J=5kg-m^{2} [/latex], [latex]B=1 N-m(rad/sec)[/latex] and [latex] K_b=1V/(rad/sec)[/latex] . The steady-state position response (in radians) due to unit impulse disturbance torque [latex]T_{d}[/latex] is_______.
solution: The transfer function due to the disturbance torque [latex] T_{d}(s) \text { is } [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{\theta(s)}{T_{d}(s)}&=\frac{-\frac{1}{(J s+B)} \times \frac{1}{s}}{1+\left(\frac{1}{J s+B}\right)\left(\frac{K_{b} K_{T}}{R_{a}+L_{a} s}\right)} \\ &=\frac{-\left(R_{a}+L_{a} s\right) \cdot \frac{1}{s}}{\left(R_{a}+L_{a} s\right)(J s+B)+K_{b} K_{T}} \end{aligned}[/latex] The steady value of response for unit impulse input [latex] \begin{aligned} &=\frac{-s\left(R_{a}+L_{a} s\right) \cdot \frac{1}{s}}{\left(R_{a}+L_{a} s\right)(J s+B)+K_{b} K_{T}}.T_{d}\\ &=-\frac{R_{a}}{R_{a} B+K_{b} K_{T}} \cdot 1\\ \text{Given:}\\ K_{T}&=1 \mathrm{N}-\mathrm{m} / \mathrm{A} R_{a}=1 \Omega \\ B&=1 \mathrm{N}-\mathrm{m} / \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{sec}\\ \text{and }\quad K_{b}&=1 \mathrm{V} / \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{sec} \end{aligned}[/latex] Substituting the given values into above equation,  we get [latex] \theta(0)=-\frac{1}{2}=-0.5 \mathrm{rad}[/latex]

question: Question 47 For the system shown in the figure, s = -2.75 lies on the root locus if K is _______.
solution: The open loop transfer function of the system: [latex] G(s) H(s)=\frac{K(s+3) \times 10}{(s+2)}[/latex] In order to lie a point s=-2.75, the angle condition must be satisfy and therefore the magnitude condition is [latex] \begin{aligned} &\mid G(s) H(s) \|_{s=-275}=1 \\ &=\left.\frac{10 K \sqrt{s^{2}+3^{2}}}{\sqrt{s^{2}+2^{2}}}\right|_{s=-2.75}=1 \\ &=\frac{10 K \sqrt{(3-2.75)^{2}}}{\sqrt{(2-2.75)^{2}}}=1 \\ &=\frac{0.25 \times 10 K}{0.75} or K=0.3 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 48 The characteristic equation of an LTI system is given by [latex]F(s)=s^{5}+2s^{4}+3s^{3}+6s^{2}-4s-8=0[/latex] The number of roots that lie strictly in the left half s-plane is _________.
solution: Using Routh's tabular or: [latex] \begin{array}{c|lll} s^{5} & 1 & 3 & -4 \\ s^{4} & 2 & 6 & -8 \\ s^{3} & 0 8 & 0(12) & 0 \\ s^{2} & 3 & -8 & 0 \\ s^{1} & \frac{100}{3} & 0 & 0 \\ s^{0} & -8 & & \end{array}[/latex] Auxiliary equation: [latex] \begin{aligned} A &=2 s^{4}+6 s^{2}-8=0 \\ \frac{d A}{d s} &=8 s^{3}+12 s=0 \end{aligned}[/latex] As one time row of zero occur in Routh's table therefore a pair of imaginary pole exists, also  number of sign change in Routh's table is one. Hence, two poles lie strictly in the left half of s-plane.

question: Question 49 Two sequences [latex]x_{1}[n] \; and \; x_{2}[n][/latex] have the same energy. Suppose [latex]x_{1}[n] = \alpha 0.5^{n} u[n] [/latex], where [latex]\alpha[/latex] is a positive real number and u[n] is the unit step sequence. Assume [latex]x_{2}[n]=\left\{\begin{matrix} \sqrt{1.5} &for n=0,1 \\ 0 & otherwise. \end{matrix}\right.[/latex] Then the value of [latex]\alpha[/latex] is _________.
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} \text { Energy of } x_{1}[n]=\sum_{n=-\infty}^{\infty}\left|x_{1}[n]\right|^{2} \\ \begin{aligned} =\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \alpha^{2} &\left(\frac{1}{4}\right)^{n}=\alpha^{2} \cdot \frac{1}{1-\frac{1}{4}}=\alpha^{2} \cdot \frac{4}{3} \\ \text { Energy of } x_{2}[n] &=1.5+1.5=3 \\ \Rightarrow \quad \alpha^{2} \frac{4}{3} &=3 \\ \alpha^{2}=\frac{9}{4} \\ \quad \alpha=1.5 \end{aligned} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 50 The variance of the random variable X with probability density function  [latex]f(x)=\frac{1}{2}|x|e^{-|x|}[/latex] is_______.
solution: [latex]f_{\lambda}(x)=\frac{1}{2}|x| e^{-x} [/latex] [latex] f_{x}(x)[/latex] is an even function. [latex] \begin{aligned} \text{So, }E(X)&=\bar{X}=\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} x f(x) d x=0 \\ \text { Variance, } & \sigma_{X}^{2}=E\left[X^{2}\right]-(\bar{X})^{2}=E\left[X^{2}\right] \\ \text { So. } \quad & \sigma_{X}^{2}=E\left[X^{2}\right]=\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} x^{2} f_{X}(x) d x\\ &=\frac{1}{2} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} x^{2}|x| e^{-|x|} d x=\int_{0}^{-\infty} x^{3} e^{-x} d x \\ &=\left[-e^{-x}\left(x^{3}+3 x^{2}+6 x+6\right)\right]_{0}^{\infty}=6 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 51 The complex envelope of the bandpass signal [latex]x(t)=-\sqrt{2}(\frac{sin(\pi t/ 5)}{\pi t/ 5})sin(\pi -\frac{\pi}{4})[/latex] , centered about [latex]f=\frac{1}{2}[/latex] Hz, is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} x(t) &=-\sqrt{2}\left[\frac{\sin \left(\frac{\pi t}{5}\right)}{\left(\frac{\pi t}{5}\right)}\right] \sin \left(\pi t-\frac{\pi}{4}\right) \\ x(t) &=\text{Re}\left[\tilde{x}(t) e^{i 2 \pi t_{c} t}\right] \\ \tilde{x}(t) &=\text { Complex envelope } \\ &=\sqrt{2}\left[\frac{\sin \left(\frac{\pi t}{5}\right)}{\left(\frac{\pi t}{5}\right)}\right] e^{i \pi / 4} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 52 A random binary wave y(t) is given by [latex]y(t)=\sum_{-\infty }^{\infty }X_{n}p(t-nT-\phi )[/latex] where u(t) = u(t) - u(t -T), u(t) is the unit step function and [latex]\phi[/latex] is an independent random variable with uniform distribution in [0,T]. The sequence {[latex]X_{n}[/latex]} consists of independent and identically distributed binary valued random variables with [latex]P\lbrace X_{n}=+1\rbrace =P \lbrace X_{n}=-1 \rbrace=0.5[/latex]  for each n. The value of the autocorrelation [latex]R_{yy}(\frac{3T}{4})\doteq E[y(t)y(t-\frac{3T}{4})][/latex]  equals ________.
solution: For a binary symmetric pulse [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore \quad R_{n}(t)&=\left[1-\frac{1}{T}\right] \\ \therefore R_{n}\left(\frac{3 T}{4}\right)&=\left[1-\frac{3 \pi / 4}{\pi}\right]=\frac{1}{4}=0.25 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 53 Consider the 3 m long lossless air-filled transmission line shown in the figure. It has a characteristic impedance of 120[latex]\pi \Omega[/latex], is terminated by a short circuit, and is excited with a frequency of 37.5 MHz. What is the nature of the input impedance ([latex]Z_{in}[/latex])?
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} l &=3 \mathrm{m} \\ f &=37.5 \mathrm{MHz} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \lambda &=\frac{3 \times 10^{8}}{37.5 \times 10^{6}}=8 \mathrm{m} \\ Z_{\text {in }}(S C) &=j Z_{0} \tan \beta l=j 120 \pi \tan \frac{2 \pi}{8} \cdot 3 \\ &=-j 120 \pi \Omega \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 54 A 200 m long transmission line having parameters shown in the figure is terminated into a load [latex]R_{L}[/latex]. The line is connected to a 400 V source having source resistance [latex]R_{S}[/latex] through a switch, which is closed at t = 0. The transient response of the circuit at the input of the line (z = 0) is also drawn in the figure. The value of [latex]R_{L}[/latex] (in [latex] \Omega [/latex]) is ________.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { At } t&=0 \\ &V_{\text {in }}=400 \times \frac{R_{0}}{R_{0}+R_{s}}=400 \times \frac{50}{200}=100 V \\ \text { At } t&=T_{0} \Gamma_{L} 100 \text { volts reflects }\\ \text { At } t&=2T_{0}\\ V_{\text {in }} &=100+\left(1+\Gamma_{\text {in }}\right) \Gamma_{L} 100=62.5 \\ \Gamma_{\text {in }} &=\frac{R_{s}-R_{o}}{R_{s}+R_{o}}=\frac{1}{2} \\ \text { Therefore, } \Gamma_{L} &=-\frac{1}{4}=\frac{R_{L}-50}{R_{L}+50} \\ R_{L} &=30 \Omega \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 55 A coaxial capacitor of inner radius 1 mm and outer radius 5 mm has a capacitance per unit length of 172 pF/m. If the ratio of outer radius to inner radius is doubled, the capacitance per unit length (in pF/m) is ________.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} C &=\frac{2 \pi \in}{ln \frac{b}{a}} \\ 172 \times 10^{-12} &=\frac{2 \pi \epsilon}{ln 5} \\ & \in \frac{172 \times 10^{-12} \times ln 5}{2 \pi} \end{aligned}[/latex] If ratio of [latex]\frac{b}{a} [/latex] is doubled then [latex] \begin{array}{l} C=\frac{2 \pi \epsilon}{\ln 10}=\frac{2 \pi \times \frac{172 \times 10^{-12} \times \ln 5}{2 \pi}}{\ln 10} \\ C=120.22 \mathrm{pF} \end{array}[/latex]
